degreeAwarded: Bachelor of Arts and Master of Public Policy
fullProgramDescription: The Economics-Public Policy B.A./M.P.P. program is an accelerated, combined degree program that allows students to earn both a B.A. in Economics and an M.P.P. in five years. The program is designed for students who are interested in pursuing a career in public policy, economics, or a related field. Students in the program take a rigorous sequence of courses in economics, statistics, and public policy, and have the opportunity to specialize in a particular area of interest.
shortProgramDescription: The Economics-Public Policy B.A./M.P.P. program is a five-year, combined degree program that prepares students for careers in public policy, economics, and related fields.
classHighlights: The program requires students to complete a series of core courses in economics, including Microeconomics (ECON 100A), Macroeconomics (ECON 100B), and Econometrics (ECON 120A).
Students also take courses in public policy, including Introduction to Public Policy (FMPH 101) and Policy Analysis (MPP 201).
Additional coursework includes Statistics for Public Policy (MPP 202) and Economic Development (ECON 173).
Students must also complete a series of electives in economics and public policy, allowing them to specialize in a particular area of interest.
The program also includes a graduate-level coursework component, where students take advanced courses in public policy and economics.
Students are also required to complete a field study or internship, providing them with practical experience in the field.
learningOutcomes: Apply economic principles to analyze public policy issues.
Use statistical methods to analyze data and inform policy decisions.
Understand the principles of public policy and the policy-making process.
Analyze the impact of policy interventions on economic outcomes.
Communicate complex policy issues effectively to diverse audiences.
Evaluate the effectiveness of policy programs and interventions.
creditRequirements: The program requires a total of 180-192 units, including 45-48 units for the M.P.P. degree.
additionalInformation: Students must apply to the M.P.P. program in the final year of their undergraduate studies. Admission to the M.P.P. program is competitive and requires a separate application.
